header.title: Overview and Guide for Wiccans in the Military

central_thesis: This pamphlet serves as an introduction to the Wiccan religion for military service members, commanders, supervisors, and chaplains, aiming to provide information to facilitate the accommodation of Wiccan spiritual needs within the U.S. military environment. It contextualizes Wiccan practices, addresses common misconceptions, and outlines relevant Department of Defense policies on religious pluralism.

structure_content.summary: Outlines the pamphlet's unofficial purpose: to introduce Wicca to service members exploring the path and to inform military leadership and chaplains about Wiccan practices to aid religious accommodation.

Defines Neo-paganism as modern reconstructions of ancient pre-Christian religions, noting their distinctness from tribal religions with clear lineages and the ongoing semantic debate around 'Neo-pagan' versus 'Pagan'.

Traces modern Wicca's origins to Margaret Murray's theories and Gerald B. Gardner's role in its public 'revival' post-1951. Discusses the evolution of Gardnerian and Alexandrian traditions, emphasizing Wicca's decentralized, non-dogmatic structure.
Clarifies that 'witchcraft' refers to the application of magical arts (weal or woe), while 'Wicca' is a specific organized religious system incorporating magic, coined and popularized by Gardner.

Categorizes Wiccan traditions into Traditional, Hereditary, Gardnerian, Alexandrian (collectively 'Traditional Craft Wicca' or TCW), and Eclectic, noting their shared foundational elements despite diverse expressions.

structure_content.chapter_title: ELEMENTS COMMON TO TRADITIONAL CRAFT WICCA (TCW) AND OTHER WICCAN TRADITIONS
structure_content.summary: Identifies four core components: Ceremonial/High Magic (ritual circles, elements, divination), Shamanistic techniques (meditation, altered states), Folk Magic (herbalism, charms), and Nature Religions (earth-based, seasonal worship).
Introduces the eight Sabbats, or 'Wheel of the Year,' based on solstices, equinoxes, and cross-quarter days, providing a comparative chart of their Gregorian dates and various ritual names.

Details significant Wiccan life transitions: Handfasting (marriage), Handparting (ritual separation), Wiccaning (newborn blessing), Welcoming (child's entry into coven), Initiatory Rites (keystone spiritual milestones), and Crossing (funeral rites).

Describes Esbats as 'working' magical and religious rites, typically coven-restricted and held during Full Moons. Discusses 'skyclad' (ritual nudity) practices, noting practical considerations for military accommodation.
Presents the Wiccan Rede poem as the religion's central ethical guide, with its core tenet: 'An ye harm none, do what ye will,' alongside the concept of the 'three-fold law'.

structure_content.chapter_title: SPIRITUAL PHILOSOPHY, ETHICS, AND PRACTICES COMMON TO MOST WICCAN GROUPS AND TRADITIONS
structure_content.summary: Contributed by Selena Fox, this section details core spiritual principles (honor Divine, do no harm, attune to Nature), values (integrity, balance), conceptualizations of the Divine (immanent, transcendent, pantheistic, polytheistic, animistic), importance of Nature, and the ritual significance of the Circle and Five Elements.

Lists and describes various tools used in Wiccan rituals, including the Altar, symbolic representations of the Divine, Elements, Circle, Season, and specific items like athames, cauldrons, chalices, and Books of Shadows.

structure_content.chapter_title: SABBATS AND THE WHEEL OF THE YEAR: SACRED CYCLE OF SUN AND SEASONS
structure_content.summary: Provides detailed descriptions for each of the eight Sabbats (Samhain, Winter Solstice, Candlemas, Spring Equinox, Beltane, Summer Solstice, Lammas, Fall Equinox), covering their alternate names, dates, colors, special tools, themes, ritual foci, and customs.

Refutes popular inaccuracies about Wicca, specifically denying human/animal sacrifice and Satan worship, clarifying the 'Three-fold Law,' and addressing misperceptions about illegal substances or sexual promiscuity.

structure_content.chapter_title: THE US MILITARY AND ALTERNATIVE RELIGIONS
structure_content.summary: Discusses the military's history of accommodating religious diversity and outlines the efforts of chaplains to support minority faith groups, emphasizing the need for flexibility from Wiccan practitioners in military settings.

structure_content.chapter_title: TITLE: DODD 1300.17, ACCOMMODATION OF RELIGIOUS PRACTICES WITHIN THE MILITARY SERVICES...
structure_content.summary: Details the Department of Defense policy (DODD 1300.17) on religious accommodation, including guidelines for worship, food, immunizations, and the wearing of religious items/apparel, alongside procedures for requests and denials.
Lists military service-specific regulations (Army, Air Force, Navy/Marines, US Coast Guard) pertaining to chaplain activities and the accommodation of religious practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: EXCERPTS FROM US ARMY CHAPLAINS HANDBOOK
structure_content.summary: Presents selected sections from the US Army Chaplains' Handbook relevant to Wicca, with a disclaimer about the content's representativeness and pending obsolescence due to objections from diverse groups.

Provides a description of Gardnerian Wicca, covering its historical origins, basic beliefs (Mother Goddess, Horned God, reincarnation, threefold retribution), practices (Wiccan Rede, secrecy), organizational structure, roles of ministers, worship customs (group, individual, skyclad), dietary laws, funeral/burial, and medical considerations.

A broader overview of Wicca as described in the handbook, detailing its autonomous covens, connection to the Covenant of the Goddess, historical roots in Nature worship, core beliefs (Sacred immanent in Nature, polytheism, magic as psychic energy), and the importance of the Book of Shadows.

Reviews significant scholarly and foundational works on Wicca and Neo-paganism, noting their authenticity, utility, and diverse perspectives, including key texts by Crowley, Starhawk, Adler, Cunningham, and Buckland.
Provides categorized lists of highly recommended, recommended, and not recommended books for further study on Wicca and related esoteric topics.
Lists contact information for various Wiccan and Pagan organizations, including Sacred Well Congregation, Greencraft België, Circle Sanctuary, and Pagan Federation.
Provides URLs for relevant online resources pertaining to Wicca and religious tolerance.
Lists national publications and periodicals relevant to the Wiccan community, such as Circle Magazine.
Contains biographical information for David L. Oringderff and Rev. S. Drake Fey, highlighting their academic and spiritual backgrounds.

key_concepts.definition: Modern reconstructions of what adherents believe to be ancient, pre-Christian Neolithic religions practiced in Classical and tribal Europe, and the Near and Middle East, distinct from tribal religions with clear historical lineages.
An organized system of religious beliefs and practices that incorporate magic (witchcraft), brought into popular usage by G. B. Gardner approximately fifty years prior to this publication.
The application of the magical arts to work weal or woe. Witches (female or male) employ witchcraft and may or may not utilize it as part of a specific religious practice.
A categorization for Gardnerian, Alexandrian, and their direct variants, stemming from a tradition originating in the New Forest area of England, which forms a core of shared practices.

American variants of Wicca, either initiated by British Tradition practitioners or self-formed, which incorporate diverse elements from other spiritualities like Santeria, African/Native American tribal religions, Hinduism, and Eastern philosophies.
A practice derived from Renaissance/Neo-Platonic magic, involving the use of magic or ritual circles, assigning correspondences to directions and elements, and complex divinatory systems.

Practices including, but not limited to, active or passive meditation, visual imagery, controlled breathing, drumming, dancing, chanting, sensory deprivation, or sensory overload, designed to shift consciousness to non-ordinary perceptual states.
Practices derived from folklore and country ways, the 'old witchcraft' in its purest sense, including herbalism, charms, spells, and other forms of sympathetic magic.

Earth-based religions, such as Wicca, that practice rites in harmony with nature, celebrating religious festivals and worship with the changing seasons and lunar phases, revering all of Gaia's children and creation as sacred.

Eight sacred festival celebrations in the Wiccan spiritual calendar, known as the Wheel of the Year, comprising the solstices, equinoxes, and midpoints between them (Cross-Quarter Days or Celtic Fire Festivals).
'Working' religious and magical rites, usually restricted to the coven or a small, intimate group, typically taking place as close as possible to the Full Moon.

The practice of ritual nudity in some Wiccan traditions, symbolizing a direct connection between the energy of the human body and the earth, and as a sign of true freedom, often practiced during Esbats.
The core ethical statement of Wicca, embodied in a poem, whose central tenet is 'An ye harm none, do what ye will', serving as a rule and guide in faith and practice.
A moral concept in Wicca that states any action, positive or negative, will return upon the doer three-fold or three times, interpreted literally or symbolically depending on the tradition.

Viewed as both immanent (indwelling) and transcendent, encompassing pantheistic, monotheistic, and polytheistic dimensions. It is honored as Mother Goddess and Father God, their unity, manifest through the Five Elements of Nature, and animistic in its presence within all living things.

The predominant ritual and social space form in Wicca, representing wholeness, balance, the cycles of Nature, continuity, partnership, and interconnectedness. It is used by individuals and groups for rituals and festivals.

Earth (North), Air (East), Fire (South), Water (West), and Spirit (Center) – a standard framework of spiritual symbology, teachings, and practice, each acknowledged in rituals with associated imagery, directions, and correspondences.
A sacred blade used for inscribing symbols, not for cutting; a tool of Air, highly personal, ritually consecrated, and often double-edged.
A personal journal, workbook, and collection of rituals, meditations, chants, and teachings, often hand-copied by initiates and typically reserved for initiated members of the religion.

A concept (coined by Rupert Sheldrake) applied to explain how ritual works, suggesting a collective or group memory that allows individuals to access and make practices easier once established, akin to Jung's collective unconscious.

Carl Jung's concept, similar to morphic resonance, representing a deeper level of human mind where individual separateness is lost, enabling phenomena like clairvoyance, telepathy, and precognition, and containing the sum of human knowledge.

practical_system.description: The Wiccan system, as presented, is an earth-based, nature-revering religion centered on the worship of a Mother Goddess and Father God. It emphasizes balance, self-mastery, healing, and living by the ethical principle of the Wiccan Rede ('An ye harm none, do what ye will') and the Three-fold Law. Practices involve attunement to natural rhythms and divine energies through rituals, often conducted in a sacred circle. While group (coven) worship is common, individual practice and adaptability in ritual execution are integral, especially in restrictive settings like the military.
tools: Altar: A small table for holding ceremonial objects, often covered with a cloth.
Symbols of the Divine: Icons, sacred paintings, sculptures, or one to three white pillar candles.
Symbol of Earth: A pentacle, platter, or dish containing salt, soil, corn meal, herbs, or ritual food like bread or fruit.
Symbol of Air: An incense burner with burning incense, a feather, bells, or an athame.
Symbol of Fire: A lamp or special candle, or a wand.
Symbol of Water: A chalice or bowl containing water, juice, or tea.
Symbol of Spirit: A personal or group symbol of spiritual wisdom, divination tools (Tarot, Runes, I Ching), or sacred jewelry (e.g., a pentagram).
Symbols of the Circle and its Directions: Four lit candles (green-N, yellow-E, red-S, blue-W), a white or purple central candle, stones, banners, cords, flowers, or corn meal.
Symbols of the Season: Varies seasonally, e.g., evergreen boughs for Yule, flowers for Spring Equinox.
Athame: A sacred blade, typically double-edged, used for inscribing symbols and directing energy, associated with the Air element; not for cutting.
Boline (Curfane/White Hilted Knife): A sacred blade, usually with a white handle, used for practical cutting, e.g., herbs, food, candle wax.
Book of Shadows: A personal journal or workbook containing rituals, meditations, chants, and teachings, often hand-copied by initiates.
Broom (Besom): Used for handfastings, purification, and as a symbol of hearth and home.
Cauldron: Often iron, used to contain earth, incense, fire, or water in rituals.
Chalice: A cup used for asperging, libations, and drinking, associated with the Water element.
Censer: An incense burner, sometimes suspended from chains.
Cord: A length of rope, ribbon, or cloth used as a ritual belt, to mark a circle, or for handfastings.
Drum: Used for sacred rhythm-making, chanting, dancing, and inner journeying.
Feather: Used with incense for consecration, associated with the Air element.
Quartz Crystal: A faceted stone used for healing, meditation, and other sacred purposes, associated with the Spirit element.
Robe: A ceremonial garment worn during rituals and celebrations.
Salt: Table or sea salt used for purification and protection, associated with the Earth element.
Sword: A large ceremonial blade used in circle casting and energy direction, not for cutting, associated with Fire and Air.
Wand: Usually made of wood, used in circle casting, energy direction, and other rituals, associated with Fire or Spirit.
rituals: Sabbats (Wheel of the Year): Eight seasonal festivals (Samhain, Yule/Winter Solstice, Imbolc/Candlemas, Ostara/Spring Equinox, Beltane, Litha/Summer Solstice, Lughnassadh/Lammas, Mabon/Fall Equinox) for celebrating natural cycles.
Moon Rites (Esbats): Magical and religious 'working' rites, typically observed near the Full Moon, often restricted to covens.

Rites of Passage: Ceremonies marking significant life transitions, including Handfasting (marriage), Handparting (ritual separation), Wiccaning (newborn blessing), Welcoming (child's entry into coven), Initiatory Rites (spiritual milestones), and Crossing (funeral rites).
Circle Casting: All rituals are typically performed within a ritually consecrated sacred circle, often marked with candles, stones, or cords, representing wholeness and sacred space.

Elemental Invocations: Acknowledgment and invocation of the Five Elements of Nature (Earth, Air, Fire, Water, Spirit) and their corresponding directions (North, East, South, West, Center) within ritual practice.
Skyclad Practice: Ritual nudity, common in some traditions during Esbats, symbolizing direct connection to earth energy and freedom, though adaptable to circumstances.

relevant_quotes.text: This pamphlet was prepared as an introduction to the Wiccan religion for those service members who are exploring Wicca as a spiritual path. It may also serve as a source of information about Wicca for commanders, supervisors, and chaplains who may have questions and concerns about specific aspects of the religion. It is hoped that this information may help facilitate the efforts of military chaplains to accommodate the spiritual needs of Wiccans in military service.
We are an old people, We are a new people, We are the same people, Stronger, wiser than before.

Wicca has no system of dogma or infallible doctrines, no "absolute" orthodoxy, and no national or international hierarchical structure per se. There is no pope, prophet, or prelate who categorically speaks for all traditions. Individual practitioners and covens are largely autonomous and answer to no organization or authority other than themselves.
The Wiccan Rede is a poem that is the embodiment of what many Wiccans use as a rule and guide in their faith and practice. ... 'An ye harm none, do what ye will'.

It is primarily at Esbats where some traditions advocate the practice of ritual nudity, which they call being "skyclad". This practice stems largely from the idea that direct connection between the energy of the human body and that of the earth is most intense when the restrictions of clothing are not present.
The Divine is honored as both Mother Goddess and Father God, as well as Their Unity. In addition, The Goddess and The God have many sacred forms or aspects.

The underlying moral concept of this principle is similar to the Christian concept of reaping what one sows. In Wicca, this concept is referred to as the 'Three-fold Law' which holds that any action, positive or negative, will return in some way upon the doer three-fold or three times.
It should also be evident that worship of Satan, or a Christian conception of a Devil who is the source of ultimate evil, is most assuredly not an element of Wiccan traditions.

To play their role in society, men must come to an understanding of how to use their male energy for greater good. The aim of the Pagan religion is not to produce men who think they are women, but men in touch with their maleness. For this, worship of God as well as Goddess is necessary. ...

I used to think Witches cast spells over people. Now I understand that true Witches work only to gain power over themselves. They work to accomplish self-mastery-- to achieve healing, wisdom, compassion and freedom, and to liberate themselves from the constraints that the world, or their upbringing, have trapped them in. Magic is a part of this process of self-awareness and liberation.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for addressing the intersection of non-mainstream spiritual practices and institutional structures, specifically within the U.S. military. It provides a foundational understanding of Wicca, dispelling common misconceptions, while simultaneously outlining the legal and procedural frameworks for religious accommodation within a hierarchical organization. Its value lies in fostering informed dialogue and promoting religious tolerance and respect for individual spiritual paths, even when they diverge significantly from dominant cultural norms.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audiences are U.S. military service members who identify as Wiccan or are exploring Wicca, military commanders, supervisors, and chaplains tasked with religious accommodation. Secondary audiences include educational institutions, non-profit organizations, and individuals interested in Western Esotericism, Neo-paganism, and the practical application of religious freedom in diverse environments.
